byline.contributor: Peter Baker contributed reporting from Portland, Ore.
byline.original: By CHARLIE SAVAGE and JONATHAN WEISMAN

abstract: United States Court of Appeals rules National Security Agency program that is systematically collecting Americans' bulk phone records is illegal; three judges say Patriot Act does not cover domestic calling records; provision is set expire June 1, and ruling is liable to ratchet up Congressional tension.
lead_paragraph: The judges ruled that the U.S.A. Patriot Act cannot be legitimately interpreted to permit the systematic gathering of domestic calling records.

headline.main: N.S.A. Collection of Bulk Call Data Is Ruled Illegal
headline.print_headline: N.S.A. Collection of Bulk Call Data Is Ruled Illegal

snippet: The judges ruled that the U.S.A. Patriot Act cannot be legitimately interpreted to permit the systematic gathering of domestic calling records.
